title: How to know if your art is no good - Quora

response.answer_text: as someone who makes art on the side, i am not going to tell you that “no art is bad.” that’s false in my personal opinion. there are some adults who make awful art that should be within the skill level of two year old, but they aren’t doing it on PURPOSE. in my opinion, bad art is defined by intent - if you didn’t mean for it to look crappy (unlike picasso), then you’re bad. anyway, i think the best way to tell whether your art is no good is to look at it is to look in the mirror if there’s no one else to judge. mirrors normally point out more imperfections than our naked eye is capable of. don’t use a camera to look through though - perspectives can be very skewed. but you can’t go wrong with a mirror.how many (random, previously un-asked) people compliment you or stop to look at your work is a good indicator. the thing is, if you draw at the lunch table or something and your art is really good, people will stop and tell you this. if your art is terrible and catastrophic, only your friends will compliment you. not a random person walking by your table.granted, sometimes people will compliment an amateur artist. there are many people who study art for a long time, so they have good technique with color or design or whatever, so a non-art invested person may believe that the art is fantastic. however, the actual skill could be shit - and yet many people would be fooled by the beautiful colors, decorations, details, etcetera. in this case, i would just recommend talking to a learned art professor/teacher. you can’t go wrong with them - they’re always looking for ways to improve students’ work, so you’ll improve even if you can’t ascertain whether or not you have good artistic ability.remember that your art can be “bad” as compared to an expert who’s been practicing for forty years! but that doesn’t mean it is actually bad. badness really is subjective, although my first paragraph still stands - there is just some wretched art out there. like said, intent.honestly? just ask anonymous people how good your art is. anons won’t lie, unless you post on social media. social media is VERY subjective and people tell bad artists they are good all the time. additionally, some popular artists are…not actually good. no youtube, no tumblr, no instagram.it’s really all about character. people who are self-aware and lack arrogance know how good (or bad) they are at art. however, sometimes you just can’t tell if your art was good or not till you come back to it like a year later. age is important, ofc, because a year can make a huge difference when it comes to skill and ability, but if you want to judge your art based off of your own standards, you will have to look at your piece(s) after a long time of not seeing them in order to judge more clearly.remember that all art looks good when you’re done with it, unless you really did such a bad job that even you yourself hate it (lmao). after staring at something for so long, it’s extremely difficult for our vision to discern whether something is actually off/incorrect or not.p.s. people can actually be “good artists” and yet still lack talent or skill. e.g. someone who produces really good abstract art should be appreciated, but if you define skill as realism or whatever, this may not adhere to your standards. that’s okay. art is very subjective. a lot of people would not agree with my opinion that bad art exists, but that’s okay too.

The word “good” is always applied within a context. My grandchild’s art is fabulous - to me, but to no one else except her mother. The art world, were you to chart it, would look like a honeycomb, filled with tiny little niches of various tastes and media in art. Cowboys, Indians, Eastern, Western, Contemporary, Modern, Traditional, Avant-Garde, Oil Paintings, Watercolors, and on and on and on and tediously on. Each one of these, and within each category, each medium, each artist, has their supporters and their detractors. Each price range has its separate standards, its own criteria. Your art fits somewhere in the honeycomb. You can be content with what the other answers have told you - “if you like it yourself, it’s good” - but no artist I know would be content with that. Every artist I have ever met is like the child who makes a drawing and races in, full of excitement, to show it to their mother - “see Mama, see!” And they wait for praise. We all want our work to be seen and acknowledged, even if we don’t admit it. And by the greater number of people, the better. The whole world is good. But how do we get that input? Well, I’ve written this before, but a longtime artist I know told me that the “only feedback you can trust is someone buying your work. Everything else is your mother telling you it’s nice.” And to a great extent I think that’s true. If someone forks over that precious “extra” money for some kind of art you created - the money that doesn’t go for housing or food, well then, that counts. It’s real. It means that for them, your art is good. In fact, it’s very good, worth something concrete and valuable. Now in order to discover this - and to potentially discover the opposite, that your art is “no good” - you have to do two things. You have to put your art in a position to be sold, and you have to price it appropriately - for its context, and for its qualifications. Clearly, a work of art online or on a street corner is not priced the same as a work of art in a serious gallery in uptown New York. A sketch is not priced like an oil painting. And a painting by a beginning artist is not priced like a work by Rembrandt. All of these considerations must be taken into account. But once they are, and you allow enough time (remember, you are looking for ONE person who loves that work of art), then perhaps, you could get a real answer to your question. But remember, even if you did set this kind of experiment up, there are a lot of famous artists who had many paintings that never sold…. and as an art dealer, I can tell you that it really is a kind of needle in a haystack thing. It can take a really long time to sell a painting - or, the right person can come along in a flash. There really is no telling. Therefore, you would really have to have a large body of work in order to discover anything. And a lot of determination - and faith. And then you could begin to find out about this “good” and “bad” stuff. It would be a process, and meanwhile, of course, you would keep trying to improve. So maybe it would be a sort of pointless proposition…… might just be better to either keep doing or quit depending on whether you were happy or not.
